questions.question: What has sales rep productivity looked like historically?
questions.answer: For a given period, sales rep productivity is calculated as: Total Bookings / (Average Effective Reps)

questions.question: What metrics are available to understand how sales is performing and what are the trends?
questions.answer: Multiple metrics are available across different sheets to understand sales performance

metrics: New Bookings / Rep (by segment - two segments)
Upsell Bookings / Rep (by segment - two segments)

metrics.details: 7 months to productivity for Account Managers (Corporate and Financial)
8 months to productivity for Account Executives (Corporate and Financial)

primary_sources.notes: Other types of reps are irrelevant because they are not in seat

questions.question: Provide a detailed explanation for how the revenue forecast is built up. What are the most important drivers and how do the forecast assumptions compare to historical actuals?
questions.answer: The revenue forecast logic is detailed in the ARR and Revenue sheet, with actuals data available through 8/31 (Column CI).

data_cutoff.description: Column CI is the last month for actuals

questions.question: What are the historical trends for LTV:CAC by segment?
questions.answer: LTV:CAC data is available in multiple locations with segment-specific breakdowns.

questions.question: Is this an investable business model?
questions.answer: Analysis requires examining the LTV:CAC methodology and customer metrics in the Dash sheet.

primary_sources.description: Contains business model methodology and customer metrics

methodology_notes.ltv_calculation: Company multiplies ARR by 3.5X (methodology not explained)

questions.question: What KPIs should management be focusing on improving?
questions.answer: KPI recommendations should be based on the business model metrics and customer performance data.

primary_sources.description: Contains key business model metrics for KPI analysis
Revenue performance and quota attainment metrics
